content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Here you go, nice puzzle

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproving.
Great graph puzzle with a nice statement. Similar to other existing puzzles but with its own twist and requires some thinking. Medium is the fitting category imho since it's limited to trees.

Got notified from CG that the approval for this puzzle should now be functional - anyone who can approve it and do so, will increment the approval count and when it counts to 3 it will update status to "Approved". 

I guess it is possible for repeated approving if the first approval was not registered.

Count on your support. Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is so nice it's the most approved on CodinGame

Looks like the approval system is stuck, failing to change status from "Pending" to "Approved". Have contacted CG to check and fix. Early news said that rescue may come on Monday when staff come back from leave. Thanks your support.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great graph puzzle with a nice statement. Similar to other existing puzzles but with its own twist and requires some thinking. Medium is the fitting category imho since it's limited to trees.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Puzzles by Java_coffee_cup, Gotta approve them all. [JK]
It's a nice puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice problem, and even better with pokemons ^_^

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is challenging and requires a level of thinking that is enjoyable and fresh

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and neat puzzle. Looks good to me.

If I understand correctly, I would write :
b. if a cell does not have an emergency exit, then <<all of>> its adjacent cell<<s>> must have one.

Looks like problems concentrate on one set of test case. I replaced D2 and its validator. I am going to write a validation program to test through all the cases again.
Thanks for your comment.

When trying to solve the puzzle, I found at least two errors in tests "Dense 2" and "Validator D2":
Dense 2 input
434 1 118
[...]
472 3 286 297 434

Validator D2 input
61 0
[...]
272 3 61 129 243

In both case, there is a cell connected to an other cell in only one direction. There are other errors like this in "Dense 2" and "Validator D2".

Other tests works fine.


Nice puzzle by the way ;)
Personally, I would set this to hard
Neat, a minimum vertex cover problem
Difficulty level could be between Medium and Hard. Now it is set to Medium. Let me know if you think the other choice is better. Tks.
Having heard community comments and rethink it overnight, I set the difficulty to Hard. But later I changed my mind and let it go to Medium again. :)

It seems there is no error left. All tests pass now.

I can share you my program in python if you wish.

Yes, you are correct. I thought by the given graph structure and restrictions already given, coders can figure out this property themselves (You did it!), so I did not explicitly point this out.
If you feel more explicit statement is better, I am happy to write a few extra words.
i want to solve it before i validate it, jumped the gun a bit, hopefully will be able to put it back on soon
That's the correct way to approve anything. Your effort can really help me and also the community.
Well, if you write b. this way, I think statement c. becomes useless.

I prefer to retain both statements b & c, to reduce the chance that the statement lead coders to think in one way but not the other way. (think from the nodes vs from the edges)

The two lines are rephrased. Looks like better than the original. Thanks your feedback.

I don't exactly remember the previous statements, but I believed they implied that an emergency exit was needed in the one cell case.
With the new statements, that cell could have no emergency exit.

The previous statement has the exact content as it is. I just changed their arrangement and a few words to indicate the two statements are logically related.

I had a little struggle with the one cell case. It needs another statement to indicate there is an emergency exit for 1-cell but this extra requirement does not have a generalized purpose. That means I have to add a special case statement and will probably cause coders to add an extra if-else in their codes, which makes the thing not at all elegant. So my decision was to remove the 1-cell test case to make it simple for everyone. I guess I would tighten the constrain to indicate N will be at least be 2 to dispel doubts.

You could replace statement c by:
c. compiling with above regulations means that if a cell does not have an emergency exit, then <<one of>> its adjacent cells must have one.
or:
c. compiling with above regulations means that if a cell is not adjacent to a cell with an emergency exit, then it must have one.

I actually liked that coders has to figure out the "all" property themself.

I like your second version. It indirectly allow the possibility of a single cell structure. By using it I will also put back the 1-cell test case in its place.
Thanks

Thank you double checking. 
The previous error data was modified from an existing source but unexpectedly it was incomplete. Now all data are generated from my source under parameter controls. It assures quality and with controlled difficulty level. Feel free to tell me should you feel anything can be improved.

Nice!
Nothing to improve in my opinion ;)
(I would set the puzzle difficulty to medium btw)
